THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Virgil Jones, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26647
Submitted March 18, 2009 - Filed May 12,
  2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  GeneralÂ  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General
  Brian T. Petrano, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Appellate
  Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of
  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this post-conviction
  relief (PCR) case, this Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of
  certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s grant of a belated direct appeal to Virgil
  Jones (Respondent) for his plea of guilty to murder, financial transaction card
  theft, and two counts of financial transaction card fraud.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On
  November 19, 1993, Respondent pled guilty to murder, financial transaction card
  theft, and two counts of financial transaction card fraud.Â  The plea judge
  sentenced Respondent to life imprisonment for murder, three years imprisonment
  for financial transaction card theft, and one year imprisonment for each count
  of financial transaction card fraud.Â  Respondent did not appeal his guilty plea
  or sentences.Â  
On October 8, 1996,
  Respondent filed a PCR application in which he alleged:Â  (1) his guilty plea
  was not knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily made; and 2) his plea counsel
  was ineffective in that counsel â€œmisadvisedâ€ him to plead guilty.Â  The State
  moved to dismiss the PCR application on the ground it was barred by the
  one-year statute of limitations as provided by the Uniform Post-Conviction
  Procedure Act.[1] Â By order dated September 15, 1997, the PCR judge dismissed Respondentâ€™s
  application. Â Respondent did not file a petition for a writ of certiorari to
  review this dismissal.
On July 9, 2003,
  Respondent filed a second PCR application in which he alleged: Â (1) he did not
  knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, (2) the
  existence of newly-discovered evidence, and (3) the plea court lacked subject
  matter jurisdiction for the murder charge.Â  
The
  State filed a Return and moved to dismiss the PCR application on the following
  grounds:Â  (1) the application was barred by the statute of limitations, (2) the
  application was barred by the doctrine of laches, (3) the claim of
  newly-discovered evidence was not cognizable in a PCR application, and (4) the
  lack of subject matter jurisdiction allegation was without merit. 
The
  PCR judge held a hearing on the Stateâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  By order dated
  November 28, 2005, the judge dismissed all of Respondentâ€™s claims as barred by
  the statute of limitations with the exception of his claim that he did not
  knowingly waive his right to a direct appeal.Â  The judge ordered a merits
  hearing on Respondentâ€™s remaining claim.
Subsequently,
  the State filed an amended Return and a motion to dismiss Respondentâ€™s
  remaining PCR allegation on the grounds the PCR application was barred as
  successive and by the doctrine of res judicata. 
At
  the merits hearing, Respondent testified that at the time of his plea, counsel
  did not inform him of his right to appeal his guilty plea.Â  Respondent claimed
  he became aware of this right after he was incarcerated for the offenses to
  which he pled guilty.Â  Respondent stated he would have requested an appeal had
  he been informed of this right at the time he pled guilty.Â  On
  cross-examination, Respondent acknowledged he never asked for a direct appeal
  until the PCR proceedings. 
Respondentâ€™s
  plea counsel testified he tells â€œall of [his] clients that they have a right to
  an appeal, if the judge does not follow the [sentencing] recommendation.â€Â  He
  claimed Respondent knew he had ten days after the plea to appeal if the judge
  did not accept the recommendation.Â  Had Respondent requested an appeal, counsel
  stated he would have filed one.
Because
  the plea judge followed the solicitorâ€™s sentencing recommendation with regard
  to Respondentâ€™s guilty plea, counsel believed there was no reason to appeal the
  negotiated plea. Â Therefore, plea counsel testified he would not have advised
  Respondent about an appeal given that â€œadvice would have already taken place.â€Â 
  Additionally, counsel stated he knew he did not advise Respondent after the
  plea proceeding regarding his right to appeal because he did not speak with the
  Respondent after the plea.
By
  order filed on September 15, 2006, the PCR judge granted Respondent a belated
  direct appeal pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35
  (1974). Â The judge directed Respondent to â€œDavis v. State, 288 S.C. 290,
  342 S.E.2d 60 (1986) for the procedure to follow in light of the Courtâ€™s
  ruling.â€ 
On
  September 22, 2006, the State sent its motion for reconsideration to the
  Richland County Clerk of Court.Â  The State, however, did not serve the circuit
  court judge with the motion until March 14, 2007.Â  The PCR judge dismissed the
  Stateâ€™s motion for reconsideration on the ground the State failed to comply
  with the ten-day service requirement of Rule 59(g)[2] of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.
This
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s
  order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered
  adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making
  all significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he or she
  is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  â€œIn the context of a guilty plea, the court must determine
  whether 1) counselâ€™s advice was within the range of competence demanded of
  attorneys in criminal cases- i.e. was counselâ€™s performance deficient, and 2)
  if there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the
  defendant would not have pled guilty.â€ Â Smith v. State, 369 S.C. 135,
  138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006) (citing Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56-58 (1985)).Â  
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  In reviewing the PCR judgeâ€™s decision, an appellate court is concerned
  only with whether any evidence of probative value exists to support that
  decision.  Smith, 369 S.C. at 138, 631 S.E.2d at 261.Â  This Court
  will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of
  probative value to support them, and will reverse the decision of the PCR judge
  when it is controlled by an error of law.  Suber v. State, 371
  S.C. 554, 558-59, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
DISCUSSION
The
  State contends the PCR judge erred in granting Respondent a belated direct
  appeal.[3]Â 
  In support of this contention, the State avers:Â  (1) Respondent did not
  reasonably demonstrate to plea counsel his desire to appeal, and (2) no
  rational defendant would have sought an appeal given the plea judgeâ€™s sentence
  did not deviate from the recommended sentence submitted by the solicitor in
  exchange for Respondentâ€™s plea of guilty to murder.Â  We agree.
â€œ[C]ounsel has a
  constitutionally imposed duty to consult with the defendant about an appeal
  when there is reason to think either (1) that a rational defendant would want
  to appeal (for example, because there are nonfrivolous grounds for appeal), or
  (2) that this particular defendant reasonably demonstrated to counsel that he was
  interested in appealing.â€Â  Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470, 480 (2000).Â  
â€œEven
  in cases when the defendant pleads guilty, the court must consider such factors
  as whether the defendant received the sentence bargained for as part of the
  plea and whether the plea expressly reserved or waived some or all appeal
  rights.â€Â  Id.Â  Absent extraordinary circumstances, there is no
  constitutional requirement that a defendant be informed of the right to a
  direct appeal from a guilty plea.Â  Turner v. State, 380 S.C. 223, 224,
  670 S.E.2d 373, 374 (2008).Â  â€œOne extraordinary circumstance which would
  require counsel to advise a defendant of the right to appeal from a guilty plea
  would arise when the defendant inquires about an appeal.â€Â  Weathers v. State,
  319 S.C. 59, 61, 459 S.E.2d 838, 839 (1995).Â  However, â€œ[t]he bare assertion
  that a defendant was not advised of appellate rights is insufficient to grant
  relief.â€Â  Id. Â â€œInstead, there must be proof that extraordinary
  circumstances exist such that the defendant should have been advised of the
  right to appeal.â€ Â Id.
For
  several reasons, we conclude the circuit court erred in finding that Respondent
  was entitled to a belated direct appeal on the ground that Respondent did not
  knowingly and intelligently waive his right to appeal from his plea.Â  
First,
  plea counsel testified and Respondent did not dispute that the plea judge
  accepted the sentencing recommendation for Respondentâ€™s plea of guilty.Â 
  Respondent also failed to offer evidence that there were any meritorious or
  viable issues for appeal.Â  Therefore, Respondent failed to establish the first
  prong of Roe in that there is no evidence that a rational defendant
  would have wanted to appeal from the guilty plea and sentence.
Secondly,
  Respondent specifically acknowledged at the PCR hearing that he did not ask
  plea counsel to file a direct appeal.Â  Plea counsel confirmed that Respondent
  never made this request despite informing Respondent prior to the plea of his
  appellate rights.Â  Thus, other than Respondentâ€™s bare assertion that he was not
  advised of his appellate rights, Respondent offered no evidence which
  reasonably demonstrated an interest in appealing.Â  Without this evidence,
  Respondent failed to satisfy the second prong of Roe.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Because
  Respondent did not produce evidence of extraordinary circumstances which would
  have required plea counsel to advise him of the right to a direct appeal, we
  hold the PCR judge erred in finding Respondent was entitled to a belated
  appellate review of his guilty plea.Â  See Turner, 380 S.C. at 225,
  670 S.E.2d at 374 (reversing order of PCR judge which found the petitioner
  entitled to a belated appellate review of his guilty plea where â€œpetitioner did
  not allege he asked counsel to file a direct appeal, he had viable issues for
  appeal, or there were other extraordinary circumstances which would require him
  to be advised of his right to a direct appeal from his guilty pleaâ€).Â 
  Accordingly, we reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s order.
In light of our
  conclusion, we decline to address the Stateâ€™s remaining argument that the PCR
  judge erred in not dismissing Respondentâ€™s second PCR application as successive.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598,
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (recognizing an appellate court need not address additional issues if the resolution of another
  issue is dispositive).

CONCLUSION
Because Respondent
  failed to establish that extraordinary circumstances existed which required
  that his plea counsel advise him of his right to a direct appeal of his guilty
  plea, we hold the PCR judge erred in granting Respondent a belated direct
  appeal.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate
  opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree that the post-conviction relief (PCR) order
  should be reversed, but write separately because I believe the case should be
  decided solely on the successive claim made by the State rather than on the
  claim of constitutionally ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  Cf., Morris
    v. Anderson County, 356 S.C. 459, 564 S.E.2d 649 (2002)(Court has well
  established policy of declining to rule on constitutional claims where they are
  unnecessary to the result).Â  Here, respondent did not raise the claim that his
  plea counsel rendered ineffective assistance in failing to advise him of his
  right to a direct appeal until his second PCR application.Â  The State argues,
  persuasively in my view, that this claim was barred as successive. Graham v.
    State, 378 S.C. 1, 661 S.E.2d 337 (2008).Â  I would reverse in a memorandum
  opinion citing Graham. 


[1]Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45 (2003). 
[2]Â  Rule 59(g) provides, â€œA party filing a written motion under this rule shall provide a copy of
  the motion to the judge within ten (10) days after the filing of the motion.â€Â 
  Rule 59(g), SCRCP.
[3]Â 
  We note that Respondent did not file for review as required by the Appellate
  Court Rules.Â  Thus, there is no belated direct appeal issue before the Court.Â  See Bennett v. State, 371 S.C. 198, 203 n.4, 638 S.E.2d 673, 675 n.4 (2006)
  (granting Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision regarding finding that plea counsel was ineffective and noting that
  there was no belated direct appeal issue before the Court given respondent did
  not file for review pursuant to Rule 227(i)(1), SCACR (now known as Rule
  243(i)(1)), and Davis); Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 291 n.1,
  342 S.E.2d 60, 60 n.1 (1986) (â€œWhen the post-conviction relief judge has
  affirmatively found that the right to a direct appeal was not knowingly and
  intelligently waived, the applicant may petition for a writ of certiorari
  pursuant to Supreme Court Rule 50, Â§ 9 . . . Even where the post-conviction relief
  judge makes this finding, he may not grant relief on this basis.Â  Instead, the
  applicant must petition this Court for a White v. State review.â€
  (emphasis added)); Rule 243(i)(1), SCACR (â€œWhere the petition seeks review
  under White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974), the following
  procedure shall be followed:Â  (1) When the post-conviction relief judge has
  affirmatively found that the right to a direct appeal was not knowingly and
  intelligently waived, the petition shall contain a question raising this issue
  along with all other post-conviction relief issues petitioner seeks to have
  reviewed.  At the same time the petition is served, petitioner shall serve
  and file a brief addressing the direct appeal issues . . . .â€).

title: Lexington Law Firm v. SCDCA
description: This direct appeal requires the Court to construe an exemption to the licensing requirements of the South Carolina Consumer Credit Counseling Act.  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 37-7-101 to -122 (Supp. 2008).  We hold that the South Carolina General Assembly intended to limit the â€œattorneys at lawâ€ exemption to attorneys authorized to practice law in this State when the attorney is â€œacting in the regular courseâ€ of his or her profession as an attorney.  We reverse the contrary holding of the administrative law court.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Lexington Law Firm, Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Consumer Affairs, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Marvin F. Kittrell, Administrative Law Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26648
Heard March 4, 2009 - Filed May 12, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Carolyn
  Grube Lybarker and Danny Raymond Collins, both of South Carolina Department of
  Consumer Affairs, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Desa
  Ballard, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  This direct appeal
  requires the Court to construe an exemption to the licensing requirements of
  the South Carolina Consumer Credit Counseling Act. Â S.C. Code Ann Â§ 37-7-101 to -122 (Supp. 2008). Â Specifically, we must determine legislative intent
  concerning the â€œattorney at lawâ€ exemption in section 37-7-101(2)(b)(i).Â  We
  hold that the South Carolina General Assembly intended to limit the â€œattorneys
  at lawâ€ exemption to attorneys authorized to practice law in this State when
  the attorney is â€œacting in the regular courseâ€ of his or her profession as an
  attorney.Â  We reverse the contrary holding of the administrative law court.
I.
The
  South Carolina Consumer Credit Counseling Act (Act) was enacted by the General
  Assembly in 2005.Â  The Actâ€™s purpose was to bring regulation and supervision to
  the world of credit counseling in South Carolina.Â  Under the Act a person may
  not engage in credit counseling in South Carolina unless properly licensed.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-7-102 (Supp. 2008).Â  This enactment was part of a national
  trend among states to protect their citizens from deceptive conduct by unscrupulous
  credit counseling organizations preying on individuals unfamiliar with credit
  repair.Â  Mary Spector, Taming the Beast: Payday
    Loans, Regulatory Efforts, and Unintended Consequences, 57 DePaul L. Rev. 961, 985 n.174 (Summer
  2008).
An
  integral feature of the Act is the need for licensure of those who engage in
  credit counseling.Â  The Act further defines credit counseling organizations but
  excludes certain professions and businesses, thus exempting them from licensure
  requirements.Â  Specifically, the Act provides:

	(2) â€œCredit
  counseling organizationâ€ means a person providing or offering to provide to
  consumers credit counseling services for a fee, compensation, or gain, or in
  the expectation of a fee, compensation, or gain, including debt management
  plans.
	(a) The business of credit counseling is
  conducted in this State if the credit counseling organization, its employees,
  or its agents are located in this State or if the credit counseling
  organization solicits or contracts with debtors located within this State.
	(b) This term does
  not include the following when acting in the regular course of their
    respective businesses and professions:
	(i) attorneys at law;
	(ii) banks, fiduciaries, credit unions,
  savings and loan associations, and savings banks as duly authorized and
  admitted to transact business in the State of South Carolina;
	(iii) a certified public accountant
  providing credit counseling advice pursuant to an accounting practice;
	(iv) title insurers and abstract companies
  doing escrow business;
	(v) judicial officers or others acting
  pursuant to court order;
	(vi) nonprofit faith-based organizations;
	(vii) counselors certified by the South
  Carolina Housing Authority to the extent engaged in counseling pursuant to
  Chapter 23, High-Cost and Consumer Home Loans. These counselors must be
  certified by the Housing Authority pursuant to Section
    37-23-40;
	(viii) mortgage brokers, real estate
  brokers, salesmen, and property managers licensed pursuant to Title 40; and
	(ix) consumer reporting agencies as
  defined by 15 U.S.C.
    Section 1681(a) (f) and any person or
  agency, or any affiliate or subsidiary of a consumer reporting agency, that
  obtains consumer reports from the agency under a certification pursuant to 15 U.S.C.
    Section 1681(e)(a) for the purpose of
  reselling the report, or information contained in or derived from the report,
  to a consumer, or monitoring information in the report on behalf of a consumer.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  37-7-101(2) (Supp. 2008).
The
  Legislature delegated to the Department of Consumer Affairs (Department)
  responsibility for administering the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-7-106 (Supp.
  2008).
The Department
  learned that a law firm based in Utah was providing credit counseling services
  to South Carolina citizens. Â The Department advised the Utah law firm of the
  Act and the need for credit counseling organizations to obtain licensure.Â  The
  Utah law firm, styling itself as Lexington Law Firm, responded to the
  Department: â€œ[f]or purposes of this letter only, Lexington [Law Firm] agrees
  that it is a credit counseling organization and provides consumer credit
  counseling as that term is defined at [section 37-7-101] (3)(b).â€Â  However, the
  Utah law firm asserted the attorney at law exemption in section
  37-7-101(2)(b)(i).
Before
  the Department could take action, Lexington Law Firm filed the underlying declaratory
  judgment action in the administrative law court (ALC) seeking a declaration
  that the Department lacks authority to issue exemptions, and moreover, a
  declaration that the law firm is entitled to the Actâ€™s attorney at law
  exemption.
The
  Department sought discovery from Lexington Law Firm in the ALC, including
  names, addresses, and bar admittances of Lexington Law Firmâ€™s attorneys.Â 
  Lexington Law Firm objected stating:

	Objection.Â 
  [Lexington Law Firm] objects to this Request on the grounds that it does not
  comply with the scope of Rule 34, SCRCP, in that it does not request any
  â€œdesignated documentsâ€ or â€œtangible things.â€Â  In addition, this Request is not
  reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of admissible evidence.Â 
  Further, this Request seeks information which is not relevant to this action,
  and the Request is intended to harass [Lexington Law Firm].

The Department
  narrowed its request in a motion to compel production stating:

	The
  Department will revise the question to ask for state certificates, licenses or
  registrations pertaining to the states in which attorneys who service/have
  serviced South Carolina consumers are admitted to practice law.Â  This item is
  relevant as the Petition states [Lexington Law Firm] engages in the practice of
  law.

Lexington Law Firm echoed its
  earlier response stating the request was â€œnot relevant.â€
It is apparent from
  the ALCâ€™s grant of summary judgment for Lexington Law Firm that the trial court
  believed the nature of the law firmâ€™s legal/credit counseling practice was
  irrelevant, for its nominal status as â€œattorneys at lawâ€ automatically entitled
  the law firm to avail itself of the attorney exemption.Â  The ALC rejected the
  Departmentâ€™s contention that the statutory exemptions are conditioned on section
  37-7-101â€™s limiting language, â€œwhen [the party seeking the exemption is] acting
  in the regular course of their respective businesses and professions.â€Â  The ALC
  ruled:

	Department
  does not have authority to grant or deny exemptions under the South Carolina
  Consumer Credit Counseling Act . . . and because the [L]egislature has already
  provided an exemption to attorneys at law under the Act, Lexington Law [Firm]
  is exempt from application of the Act and not subject to regulation by the
  Department . . . .

The
  Departmentâ€™s appeal is before us pursuant to Rule 204(b) certification, SCACR.
II.
The
  Department contends it has the authority, in the first instance, to determine
  if a credit counseling organization is exempt from the Actâ€™s licensing
  requirements.Â  The Department additionally asserts that Lexington Law Firm is
  not entitled to the attorney at law exemption under the Act.Â  We agree with the
  Department on both counts.
A.
The Departmentâ€™s Authority
The
  Department has authority over licensing under the Act, and that authority
  encompasses the initial determination, subject to judicial review, of whether a
  credit counseling organization satisfies a statutory exemption.[1]Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-7-106 (Supp. 2008).
Section
  37-7-106 empowers the Department to â€œrefuse to license an applicant or suspend
  or revoke a license or refuse to renew a license issued pursuant to this
  chapter if it finds, after notice and a hearing pursuant to the Administrative
  Procedures Act,â€ the applicant was convicted of a felony or fraud; violated a
  provision of the Act; used fraud to obtain a license; participated in continuous
  unfair conduct; went bankrupt; or violated a reasonable rule or regulation made
  by the Department.Â  Additionally, as Lexington Law Firm conceded at oral
  argument, the statute provides a two-step test to determine if a business is
  exempt.Â  First, the business must qualify as one of the exempt categories and
  second, the organization must be acting in the regular course of its business.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-7-101(2)(b).
Therefore,
  as the Department is charged by the Legislature with issuing licenses and is in
  the best position to implement the statutory test, we hold the Department is
  authorized to determine if a party is exempt from obtaining a license.Â  See
    City of Rock Hill v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 302 S.C. 161,
  165, 394 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1990) (â€œAs creatures of statute, regulatory bodies .
  . . possess only those powers which are specifically delineated.Â  By necessity
  however, a regulatory body possesses not only the powers expressly conferred on
  it but also those which must be inferred or implied to effectively carry out
  the duties for which it is charged.â€) (citing City of Columbia v. Bd. of
    Health and Envtl. Control, 292 S.C. 199, 202, 355 S.E.2d 536, 538 (1987)).Â 
  Furthermore, this Court should defer to the Departmentâ€™s findings where there
  is no compelling reason to reject it.Â  Faile v. S.C. Employment Sec. Commâ€™n,
  267 S.C. 536, 540, 230 S.E.2d 219, 221-22 (1976) (â€œThe construction of a
  statute by the agency charged with executing it is entitled to the most
  respectful consideration and should not be overruled without cogent reasons.â€).
B.
The Attorney at Law
  Exemption
Lexington
  Law Firm, as a matter of law, is not entitled to the â€œattorneys at lawâ€
  exemption.Â  As previously discussed, section 37-7-101(2) provides:

	(2)
  â€œCredit counseling organizationâ€ means a person providing or offering to
  provide to consumers credit counseling services for a fee, compensation, or
  gain, or in the expectation of a fee, compensation, or gain, including debt
  management plans.
	(a)
  The business of credit counseling is conducted in this State if the credit
  counseling organization, its employees, or its agents are located in this State
  or if the credit counseling organization solicits or contracts with debtors
  located within this State.
	(b)
  This term does not include the following when acting in the regular course
    of their respective businesses and professions:
	(i) attorneys
  at law;

(emphasis added).
None of the
  attorneys in Lexington Law Firm is authorized to practice law in South Carolina. The position of Lexington Law Firm is manifestly without merit.Â  To accept
  Lexington Law Firmâ€™s view of the statute, we must accept the premise that the
  Legislature has sanctioned the unauthorized practice of law.Â  The Legislature
  has done no such thing.
â€œThere
  is a presumption that the [L]egislature has knowledge of previous legislation
  as well as of judicial decisions construing that legislation when later
  statutes are enacted concerning related subjects.â€Â  State v. McKnight,
  352 S.C. 635, 648, 576 S.E.2d 168, 175 (2003).Â  Thus, when enacting the Act,
  the General Assembly knew of South Carolinaâ€™s laws and policies addressing the
  unauthorized practice of law, including section 40-5-310 of the South Carolina Code (2001) which makes it a crime to engage in the unauthorized
  practice of law.Â  We therefore hold the General Assembly would not create an
  exemption condoning the unauthorized practice of law.[2]
Moreover,
  section 37-7-101(2)(b)â€™s conditional â€œregular course of . . . businessâ€
  language is unambiguous.Â  The language indicates a clear legislative intent to limit
  the exemption to a listed business (or profession) when the credit counseling
  service is part of the regular course of that business.Â  If a statutorily
  enumerated business provides credit counseling services not in the regular
  course of its business, the exemption is unavailable.Â  McClanahan v.
    Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002) (â€œAll
  rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative
  intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used,
  and that language must be construed in light of the intended purpose of the
  statute.â€) (citation omitted); First Baptist Church of Mauldin v. City of
    Mauldin, 308 S.C. 226, 229, 417 S.E.2d 592, 593 (1992) (â€œIn construing a
  statute, its words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without
  resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s
  operation.â€) (citation omitted).
Further,
  the statuteâ€™s plain language indicates the Legislature intended to exempt professions
  and businesses that are otherwise regulated.Â  Other exemptions located in this
  section are of other professions and businesses subject to other licenses (such
  as certified public accountants, counselors certified by the South Carolina
  Housing Authority, and real estate brokers licensed pursuant to Title 40) as
  well as non-profit, faith-based organizations and judicial officers.Â 
  Therefore, the Legislature expressed its intent to exempt businesses otherwise
  licensed in South Carolina and non-profit organizations.
Lexington Law Firmâ€™s
  final argument is that the providing of credit counseling services does not
  constitute the practice of law, and as such, its actions cannot constitute the
  unauthorized practice of law.Â  The untenable dichotomy Lexington Law Firm
  advances is they fall under the attorney exemption but do not commit the
  unauthorized practice of law in South Carolina because they are conducting a
  business. Â Lexington Law Firm cannot have it both ways.Â  As discussed, the
  statutory scheme limits the listed exemptions to those professions or
  businesses â€œwhen acting in the regular course of their respective businesses
  and professions.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-7-101(2)(b) (Supp. 2008).Â  If Lexington Law
  Firm is, in fact, acting in the regular course of the practice of law in South Carolina, then it is engaging in the unlawful unauthorized practice of law.Â 
  Conversely, if Lexington Law Firm is merely conducting a credit counseling
  business, then it may not gain relief from the statutory compliance
  requirements through the â€œattorneys at lawâ€ exemption.
III.
In
  sum, we are not barring Lexington Law Firm from providing credit counseling
  services to South Carolinians, we are simply requiring Lexington Law Firm
  comply with the statutes enacted by our Legislature.Â  Lexington Law Firm may
  not avail itself of an exemption for which it is not statutorily entitled.
We hold Lexington
  Law Firm is not exempt under section 37-7-101(2)(b) from licensure requirements
  and the Department of Consumer Affairs is statutorily empowered to determine if
  a business qualifies for an exemption.Â  The judgment of the ALC is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1]  At
  oral argument, Lexington Law Firm contended the Departmentâ€™s appropriate course
  of action would be to issue a cease and desist order under section 37-7-119.Â 
  Under normal circumstances, we would agree, but Lexington Law Firm preempted
  the normal course of these actions by the filing of its declaratory judgment
  action.Â  Lexington Law Firm may not now complain that the Department failed to
  follow the preferred statutory course.
[2]  The authority to practice law in South
  Carolina arises in three circumstances: (1) a license to practice law from this
  Court; (2) authorization pro hace vice under Rule 404, SCACR; or (3) a
  limited certificate of admission under Rule 405, SCACR.

title: In the Matter of Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr.
description: This attorney disciplinary action arises out of multiple allegations of misconduct including misappropriation of funds.  We disbar Thomas E. Ruffin effective from the date of this opinion.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court
In the Matter of Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr.,
  Respondent.

Opinion No. 26649
Heard February 18, 2009 - Filed May 12,
  2009
DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry D. McMaster and Senior Assistant Attorney General James G. Bogle,
  Jr., both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				George
  Hunter McMaster of Tompkins & McMaster, of Columbia, and Irby E. Walker,
  Jr., of Conway, for respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This attorney disciplinary action arises out of
  multiple allegations of misconduct including misappropriation of funds.Â 
  Following a hearing, the Commission on Lawyer Conduct recommended Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr., be disbarred.Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel joined
  in the recommendation.Â  After thorough review of the record, we agree and
  disbar Ruffin effective from the date of this opinion.
In
  this attorney disciplinary case, Ruffin is accused of multiple acts of
  misconduct including misappropriation of trust account funds and failure to pay
  a client his settlement.Â  Ruffin was placed on interim suspension on July 28,
  2004.Â  In the Matter of Ruffin, 360 S.C. 339, 600 S.E.2d 909 (2004).Â 
  Subsequently, in an unrelated matter, this Court indefinitely suspended
  Ruffin.Â  In the Matter of Ruffin, 363 S.C. 347, 359-60, 610 S.E.2d 803,
  809 (2005).Â  In the case at hand, the Commission on Lawyer Conduct panel found
  misconduct occurred and recommended Ruffin be disbarred without retroaction,
  required to pay costs, and required to make full restitution.Â  We hold
  disbarment without retroaction, costs, and restitution are warranted sanctions.
Matter
  I
Ruffin conducted a
  refinancing for Client A on or about April 16, 2004.Â  On April 21, 2004,
  $137,896.51 was wired to Ruffinâ€™s trust account to be used to pay off the first
  mortgage.Â  Ruffin failed to pay off the first mortgage, and the balance of his
  trust account on April 30, 2004 was $9,109.97, far short of the amount
  necessary to pay off the first mortgage.
The
  title insurance company insuring the closing dispatched an auditor to review
  Ruffinâ€™s trust account.Â  The auditor found the payoff never occurred and a
  pattern of late payoffs using one closing to fund a previous closing.Â  For
  instance, Ruffin conducted a closing for Client B on or about March 26, 2004.Â 
  The $114,406.27 payoff check was dated March 26, 2004, but did not clear until
  April 26, 2004, after the above mentioned Client Aâ€™s funds were deposited in
  Ruffinâ€™s trust account.Â  Additionally, Ruffin conducted a closing for Client C
  on January 15, 2004, but the payoff check did not clear until February 24,
  2004.Â  In the interim, Ruffinâ€™s trust account balance dipped to approximately
  $7,000, well below the necessary amount to cover Client Câ€™s payoff.
Matter II
Ruffin represented a
  client in a personal injury claim.Â  The claim was settled for $3,500.00.Â 
  Ruffinâ€™s trust account showed the funds were deposited on May 6, 2004.Â  Ruffin
  never issued a check to his client. Â The trust accountâ€™s balance at the end of
  May 2004 was $309.97, which was again too depleted to cover Ruffinâ€™s financial
  obligation.
In his answer,
  Ruffin admitted he failed to pay his client.Â  Ruffin argued in his brief that
  he was owed $2,500 by another party and once he placed that in his trust account
  he would be able to pay his client.Â  This is a prime example of Ruffinâ€™s
  misunderstanding of the sanctity of a trust account.
Matter III
When this Court
  ordered Ruffinâ€™s interim suspension in 2004, the Court appointed an Attorney to
  Protect Clientsâ€™ Interests.Â  In the Matter of Ruffin, 360 S.C. at 340,
  600 S.E.2d at 909.Â  As part of his service, the appointed attorney reported an
  item for $100.00 was returned for insufficient funds in one of Ruffinâ€™s trust
  accounts in March 2004.Â  However, the insufficient funds notice stated, â€œNotice
  of Returned Deposited Item.â€Â  Therefore, we find the bank notified Ruffin that
  a $100 check he deposited had insufficient funds, not that he wrote a check
  with insufficient funds.Â  Accordingly, no misconduct occurred in this matter.
Matter
  IV
The appointed
  attorney also reported this matter, which involves Ruffinâ€™s representation of a
  client in a personal injury case.Â  The clientâ€™s medical insurer notified the
  client and Ruffin that it believed it had a right to recover its costs if the
  client settled the claim.Â  The case settled for $17,500, which was deposited in
  Ruffinâ€™s trust account.Â  In October 2003, the client authorized the
  disbursement of $5,523.53 to the medical insurer, and Ruffin sent the client a
  check for the remainder less attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Ruffin, however, never paid the
  medical insurer, and his trust account had a balance of $93.50 on January 30,
  2004.
Ruffin admitted the
  client signed the disbursement authorization but denies any misappropriation.Â 
  Ruffin argued he determined the medical insurer was not entitled to this money,
  contacted the client, and reached an agreement with the client to put the
  $5,523.53 towards legal fees owed by the client.Â  Upon review of the record, we
  hold Ruffin failed to fulfill his agreement with the medical insurer.Â  Further,
  Ruffin provided no evidence to substantiate his assertion he and the client
  reached an agreement to apply the withheld funds to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Instead,
  the record only includes the disbursement agreement signed by the client
  indicating a $5,523.53 payment should be issued to the medical insurer.Â  We
  find unpersuasive Ruffinâ€™s effort to explain this gross misconduct.
Matter V
Ruffin sent evidence
  related to a motor vehicle accident to a retired civil engineering professor to
  review.Â  Ruffin asked the professor to render an opinion related to the motor
  vehicle accident.Â  The professor did so and submitted his bill of $250 to
  Ruffin but was never paid for his services.Â  In his answer, Ruffin admitted he
  never paid the professor because Ruffin sent the bill to his clients for
  payment.Â  We find this argument meritless.Â  Ruffin contacted the professor to
  review documents, and despite the professorâ€™s repeated contact with Ruffin
  regarding payment, Ruffin never paid the professor.Â  Having contracted with the
  professor, without the clientâ€™s knowledge or consent, Ruffinâ€™s failure to pay
  the professor constitutes misconduct.
Matter VI
A
  homeownersâ€™ association retained Ruffin to collect dues from two delinquent
  homeowners.Â  The association paid Ruffin a total of $3,559.30.Â  Ruffin wrote a
  letter to each of the delinquent homeowners but did not file the liens against
  their property after delinquent homeowners failed to pay.Â  Ruffin admitted that
  he failed to refund the fee.Â  Ruffin further agreed a portion of his payment
  should be repaid.
Matter VII
In his answer,
  Ruffin conceded he failed to respond timely to the Notices of Full
  Investigation/Supplemental Notices of Full Investigation in these cases.

Panel Report
The panel found multiple
  violations of the Rules of Professional Conduct (RPC) contained in Rule 407,
  SCACR.Â  Specifically, the panel found the following RPC violations in Matter I,
  Matter II, Matter IV, and Matter VI: Rule 1.1, Competence; Rule 1.2, Scope of
  Representation; Rule 1.3, Diligence; Rule 1.4, Communication; and Rule 1.15,
  Safe Keeping of Property.Â  Additionally, in Matters V and VI, the panel found a
  violation of Rule 4.1, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR, Truthfulness in Statements to Others.
As
  for Ruffinâ€™s admitted failure to cooperate, the panel found a violation of RPC Rule
  8.1(b), Failure to Respond to a Lawful Demand for Information from a
  Disciplinary Authority. Â Further, the panel found a violation of Rule 7(a)(3),
  Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement (RLDE) contained in Rule 413, SCACR,
  because Ruffin failed to respond to a disciplinary authorityâ€™s lawful demand.
Lastly, the panel
  found with regards to all matters, that Ruffin violated RPC Rule 8.4 in his
  violation of Rules of Professional Conduct, inability to account for funds
  entrusted to him, and perpetration of conduct prejudicial to the administration
  of justice.
The panel recommended
  Ruffin be disbarred effective on the date of this Courtâ€™s opinion, required to
  pay costs of the proceedings, and required to make full restitution.Â  The panel
  suggested Ruffin make the following restitution payments: $116,703.36 to the
  title insurance company in Matter I, $1,803.24 to Ruffinâ€™s client in Matter II,
  $5,523.53 to the medical insurer in Matter IV, $313.54 to the professor in
  Matter V, and $2,000 to the gentleman who repaid the homeownersâ€™ association in
  Matter VI.
Law/Analysis
â€œThis
  Court is not bound to accept the recommendations of the Panel or the Executive
  Committee.Â  The duty of adjudging the professional conduct of members of the
  Bar and taking appropriate disciplinary action rests exclusively with this
  Court.â€Â  In the Matter of Hines, 275 S.C. 271, 273, 269 S.E.2d 766, 767
  (1980).
We
  hold no misconduct occurred in Matter III as the insufficient notice dealt with
  an item deposited in Ruffinâ€™s account, not a check written on the account.Â 
  Regarding the remaining matters, we agree with the panel report and find
  misconduct.Â  We further require restitution as set forth by the panel.
Due
  to the clear and convincing evidence of misconduct, Ruffinâ€™s disciplinary
  history, and this Courtâ€™s precedent, we hold nonretroactive disbarment is
  appropriate.Â  In the Matter of Ruffin, 363 S.C. at 359-60, 610 S.E.2d at
  809 (indefinitely suspending Ruffin for matters unrelated to this case); see
    also In the Matter of Wilmeth, 373 S.C. 631, 636, 647 S.E.2d 185,
  188 (2007) (disbarring attorney, not retroactively, for multiple acts of
  misconduct including misappropriation of funds); In the Matter of Morehouse,
  330 S.C. 205, 206-07, 499 S.E.2d 208, 209 (1998) (disbarring attorney without
  retroaction for wire fraud).
Under
  Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, we further require Ruffin to contact ODC immediately
  regarding setting up a restitution plan.Â  Ruffin shall agree on a restitution payment
  plan with ODC within sixty days of the filing of this opinion, complete
  restitution prior to petition for reinstatement, pay the costs associated with
  the disciplinary proceedings within ninety days of the filing of this opinion,
  and take the Legal Ethics and Practice Program sponsored by ODC and the Professional Responsibility Committee of the South
  Carolina Bar prior to any petition for reinstatement.Â  Failure to comply with
  the restitution plan may result in the imposition of civil or criminal contempt
  by this Court.
Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we disbar Ruffin effective upon the filing date of this
  opinion.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, Ruffin shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30,
  Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to
  Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

DISCUSSION
The Insurer argues the circuit court erred in finding
  it had a continuing duty to defend the City after the cause of action for
  negligent misrepresentation was dismissed.Â  The Insurer claims its duty to
  defend terminated at this point because any remaining duty to defend the City

â€œA suit for declaratory
  judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the
  underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400
  S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  A suit to determine coverage under an insurance policy

  86, 93, 522 S.E.2d 345, 348-49 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Therefore, this Courtâ€™s
  jurisdiction â€œis limited to correcting errors of law and factual findings will
  not be disturbed unless unsupported by any evidence.â€ Â Id.
Questions of
  coverage and the duty of a liability insurance company to defend a claim
  brought against its insured are determined by the allegations of the complaint.Â  C.D. Walters Constr. Co. v. Firemanâ€™s Ins. Co. of Newark, N.J., 281 S.C.
  593, 316 S.E.2d 709 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  If the underlying complaint creates a
  possibility of coverage under an insurance policy, the insurer is obligated to
  defend. Â Gordon-Gallup Realtors, Inc. v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 274 S.C.
  468, 265 S.E.2d 38 (1980).

  insurerâ€™s duty to defend is
  separate and distinct from its obligation to pay a judgment rendered against an

  183, 236 S.E.2d 818 (1977).Â  However, these duties are interrelated. Â If the
  facts alleged in a complaint against an insured fail to bring a claim within
  policy coverage, an insurer has no duty to defend. R.A. Earnhardt Textile Mach. Div. v. S.C. Ins.

â€œAlthough

I.
As its first
  argument, the Insurer contends it had no duty to defend the City regarding
  Byrdâ€™s cause of action for civil conspiracy because it was not specifically
  pled and, thus, did not invoke potential liability coverage. 
Although
  the Insurer conceded this issue during oral argument before this Court, we take
  this opportunity to reiterate the standard for determining an insurerâ€™s duty to
  defend.Â  
Based
  on the above-outlined principles, we find Byrdâ€™s failure to plead the elements

  the complaint that are known to the insurer.
In the instant
  case, the City acknowledged that Byrd did not specifically plead civil
  conspiracy in his original or amended complaints.Â  However, as evidenced by the
  circuit courtâ€™s orders, the allegations in these pleadings set forth Byrdâ€™s

II.
Even if Byrd had pled conspiracy, the Insurer avers that this claim did
  not provide a basis for coverage independent from that of the inverse
  condemnation cause of action.Â  Specifically, the Insurer contends that the â€œheart
  of the conspiracy claim is â€˜flagging,â€™ which cannot be separated from the
  inverse condemnation claim against the County.â€ Â Relying on the policy language

  condemnation is excluded under the liability policy, the Insurer argues it had
no duty to defend the City against the civil conspiracy claim.Â  
For several reasons, we disagree with the Insurerâ€™s contention.Â  First,
it is instructive to examine the elements of inverse condemnation and civil conspiracy.
The
  elements of an inverse condemnation are (1) affirmative conduct of a
  governmental entity, and (2) a taking.Â  Byrd v. City of Hartsville, 365
  S.C. 650, 657, 620 S.E.2d 76, 79-80 (2005).
In
  contrast, the tort of civil conspiracy contains three elements:Â  Â (1) the
  combination of two or more people, (2) for the purpose
  of injuring the plaintiff, (3) which causes special damages.Â  Pye v. Estate
    of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 566-67, 633 S.E.2d 505, 511 (2006); Kuznik v. Bees
      Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 610, 538 S.E.2d 15, 31 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œIt is
  well-settled in South Carolina that the tort of civil conspiracy contains three
  elements: Â (1) a combination of two or more persons; (2) for the purpose of
  injuring the plaintiff; (3) causing plaintiff special damage.â€).
â€œAn
  action for civil conspiracy may exist even though respondents committed no
  unlawful act and no unlawful means were used.â€ Â LaMotte v. Punch Line of
    Columbia, Inc., 296 S.C. 66, 70, 370 S.E.2d 711, 713 (1988).Â  â€œSpecifically,
  it is not necessary for a plaintiff asserting a civil conspiracy cause of
  action to allege an unlawful act in order to state a cause of action, although
  a civil conspiracy may be furthered by an unlawful act.â€ Id. Â â€œThus,
  lawful acts may become actionable as a civil conspiracy when the object is
    to ruin or damage the business of another.â€ Id. (citations omitted)
  (emphasis added). Â 
â€œThe
  gravamen of the tort of civil conspiracy is the damage resulting to the
  plaintiff from an overt act done pursuant to the combination, not the agreement
  or combination per se.â€Â  Pye, 369 S.C. at 567-68, 633 S.E.2d at 511.Â 
  â€œBecause the quiddity of a civil conspiracy claim is the damage resulting to
  the plaintiff, the damages alleged must go beyond the damages alleged in other
    causes of action.â€Â  Id. at 568, 633 S.E.2d at 511 (emphasis added).
Â As
  evidenced by the above-outlined principles, the elements and damages for the
  two causes of action are distinctly different. 
Initially,
  we note the â€œobjectâ€ of the alleged civil conspiracy is not entirely clear from
  the pleadings.Â  Conceivably, such a conspiracy could have been intended to prevent
  Byrd from commercially developing the City tract but also from developing any
  other potentially acquired properties in the City or the County.Â  Had the City
  and the County actually conspired, such a conspiracy could have had further

  property.
In
  terms of the elements of the causes of actions, a claim for civil conspiracy
  would have required Byrd to establish the existence of an overt act committed
  by a combination of individuals for the purpose of injuring Byrd.Â  These
  elements were not present in Byrdâ€™s claim for inverse condemnation.Â  Moreover,
  in order to prevail on his civil conspiracy claim, Byrd did not have to prove
  that a â€œtakingâ€ occurred.
Secondly,
  it is significant that the circuit court permitted Byrd to pursue his
  conspiracy claim after the court simultaneously dismissed the inverse
  condemnation cause of action.Â  Clearly, this decision evidenced the circuit
  courtâ€™s belief that Byrdâ€™s claim of civil conspiracy was a tort action that
  existed separate and independent from the inverse condemnation claim.Â  Although
  the conspiracy claim was ultimately dismissed by the circuit court under the
  Tort Claims Act, we find the Insurer had a continuing duty to defend as long as
  there was a possibility of liability coverage for this tort claim.Â  Â 
Moreover, a review of the applicable exclusion in the liability policy
  does not support the Insurerâ€™s argument.Â  The Insurer relies on the following
language:

  Inverse condemnation, condemnation, temporary taking,
    permanent taking, or any claim arising out of or in any
      way connected with the operation of the principles of eminent domain;
    adverse possession or dedication by adverse use. (emphasis added). 

Even
  though the facts of both causes of action were â€œintertwined,â€ Byrdâ€™s claim for

  any policy exclusion should be construed narrowly and in favor of the City.Â  Because

III.
Next,
  the Insurer asserts the circuit court erred in finding that the Tort Claims Act[6] required it to provide coverage for the conspiracy claim and, in turn,
  established a duty to defend the City against this cause of action.Â  In support
  of this assertion, the Insurer relies on the provision of the Tort Claims Act
  which grants sovereign immunity to a political entity for the intentional acts
  of its employees.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(17) (2005) (stating a
  â€œgovernmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from:Â  employee conduct
  outside the scope of his official duties or which constitutes . . . intent to
  harmâ€).Â  
In
  view of this provision, the Insurer argues that â€œclaims based on intentional
  harm such as conspiracy are barred by sovereign immunity under section
  15-78-60(17).â€ Â Therefore, the Insurer contends that â€œif there is no liability
  under the Tort Claims Act, [the City] has no grounds for arguing that coverage
  must be provided.â€Â  Based on this reasoning, the Insurer avers it had no duty
  to defend the conspiracy claim.Â  
The Tort Claims Act provides that â€œ[t]he State, an agency, a political
  subdivision, and a governmental entity
  are liable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as a
  private individual under like circumstances, subject to the limitations upon
  liability and damages, and exemptions from liability and damages, contained
herein.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-40 (2005). 
â€œThe burden of establishing a
  limitation upon liability or an exception to the waiver of immunity under the Tort Claims Act
  is upon the governmental entity asserting it as an affirmative defense.â€Â  Plyer
    v. Burns, 373 S.C. 637, 651, 647 S.E.2d 188, 195-96 (2007).Â  â€œProvisions
  establishing limitations upon and exemptions from liability of a governmental
entity must be liberally construed in favor of limiting liability.â€Â  Id.
Notably, it appears
  the Insurer confuses its duty to defend with its obligation to pay for a
  covered claim.Â  As we interpret its argument, the Insurer believes that if the
  City is immune under the Tort Claims Act for civil conspiracy claims then there
  is no liability coverage and, in turn, no duty to defend.
This argument, however,
  ignores the fact that sovereign immunity is an affirmative defense which must
  be raised by the party asserting it as a bar to liability. Â Logically, then the
  Insurer had a duty to assert this defense on behalf of the City.Â  Thus, the
  fact that the circuit court ultimately dismissed Byrdâ€™s conspiracy claim under
  the Tort Claims Act is of no consequence to a determination of whether the
  Insurer had a duty to defend the City on this claim.Â  See Town of
    Duncan, 326 S.C. at 16 n.14, 482 S.E.2d at 774 n.14 (â€œAn insurerâ€™s duty to
  defend depends on an initial or apparent potential liability to satisfy a
  judgment against the insured.â€).
IV.
Finally,
  even if it had a duty to defend the City against the conspiracy claim, the
  Insurer contends the circuit court erred in finding the duty continued after
  the circuit court dismissed the claim and Byrd failed to appeal the dismissal. 
Because
  we hold the Insurer had a continuing duty to defend the City even after the
  negligent misrepresentation claim was dismissed, we agree with the circuit
  courtâ€™s assessment of costs against the Insurer.Â  See Unisun Ins. Co.
    v. Hertz Rental Corp., 312 S.C. 549, 554, 436 S.E.2d 182, 186 (Ct. App.

  defense.â€). Â 
As
  acknowledged by the Insurer, the liability policy provided for the Insurer â€œto
  indemnify [the City] all costs and expenses incurred in the investigation,
  adjustment, settlement, defense and appeal of any claim or suit for
  which coverage is afforded by this Section III (General Liability) of this

  costs and expenses incurred by the City through the appeal of Byrdâ€™s lawsuit.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the Insurer had a
  continuing duty to defend the City even after the negligent misrepresentation

  bills.Â  After judgment was granted to the class, the City sought
  indemnification from its insurer.Â  Id. at 241, 628 S.E.2d at 277.Â  In
  turn, the insurer filed a declaratory judgment requesting declarations that its
  liability policy with the City did not cover any of the claims or damages
  asserted by the class.Â  In support of its action, the insurer relied on a
  policy provision which specifically excluded inverse condemnation actions.Â 
  Because the policy excluded coverage for inverse condemnation actions, the
  insurer contended the class membersâ€™ claim of a taking in violation of equal
  protection and due process was also excluded from coverage.Â  Id. at 242,
  628 S.E.2d at 277.Â  After converting the motion into cross-motions for summary
judgment, the trial court ruled in favor of the City.Â  The insurer appealed.Â  Id. at 243, 628 S.E.2d at 277. 
Addressing only the
  insurerâ€™s contention that its policy expressly excluded coverage for claims
  based on a taking, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court.Â  Id. at 244, 628 S.E.2d at 278.Â  In so ruling, the court specifically noted that the
  focus of the appeal was on the coverage provided by the liability policy and
  not the insurerâ€™s duty to defend.Â  On the merits, the court found that the
  insurer should not have been required to indemnify the City for its loss because
  â€œthe violation of the class membersâ€™ rights to due process and equal protection
  would not have occurred but for the wrongful exercise by the City of its
  eminent domain power,â€ which in turn fell within the inverse condemnation
policy exclusion.Â  Id. at 245, 628 S.E.2d at 278-79.
We believe the City
  of Myrtle Beach is distinguishable from the instant case given it involved
  the insurerâ€™s duty to indemnify and not the initial duty to defend.Â 
  Furthermore, unlike Byrdâ€™s claim of civil conspiracy, the class membersâ€™ claim
  of a taking, which included allegations of due process and equal protection
  violations, necessarily arose out of the Cityâ€™s exercise of its eminent domain
power.
[6]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 through -220 (2005 &
Supp. 2008).

The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina

In the Matter of Joseph L. Smalls, Jr.,
Respondent.

ORDER

This Court retroactively disbarred
  Joseph L. Smalls.Â  See
    In the Matter of Smalls, Op. No. 26634 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Apr. 13, 2009) (Shearouse Adv. Sh.
  No. 16 at 71).Â  Smalls petitioned this Court to reconsider its requirement
  Smalls make full restitution prior to petitioning for reinstatement.Â  This
  Court hereby withdraws the opinion dated April 13, 2009 and substitutes the attached
opinion.
IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
     
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           A.C.J.
              
              s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
            s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
      s/John W. Kittredge                           J.
      Acting
  Justice James E. Moore not participating.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
May 18, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

In the Matter of Joseph L. Smalls, Jr.,
Respondent.

Opinion No. 26634
  Heard March 17, 2009 - Re-filed May 18,
2009

DISBARRED


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry D. McMaster and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Bogan
          both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        I. S.
          Leevy Johnson of Johnson, Toal & Battiste, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, Joseph L. Smalls, Jr., stipulated to misconduct primarily involving his
  trust accounts.Â  The Commission on Lawyer Conduct panel recommended retroactive
  disbarment, restitution, and assessment of costs.Â  We find retroactive disbarment,
  restitution, and costs warranted.
I.
Smalls
  ran the Smalls Law Firm, in Columbia, which consisted of a general practice
  with a high volume of real estate closings.Â  Smalls solely possessed check
  signing authority and maintained control over the firmâ€™s bank accounts related
  to this case.
Smalls
  stipulated this case arose out of a complaint to Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) because a check for $72,379.67 issued by Smalls for a real estate closing
  was not honored in 2002.Â  The complaint launched a full ODC investigation into
  Smallsâ€™ multiple law firm bank accounts.Â  As a result of its investigation, ODC
  petitioned for interim suspension, which this Court granted on May 16, 2002.
Additionally,
  Smalls conceded he failed to identify client file names or numbers as required
  by Rule 417, SCACR on â€œscoresâ€ of deposits between 2000 and 2002 into his trust
  accounts.Â  Smalls further admitted he routinely transferred funds between law
  firm accounts to â€œcureâ€ account shortages.Â  This misconduct resulted in
  multiple insufficient funds penalties and fees.Â  One of Smallsâ€™ trust accounts
  was assessed penalties for approximately seventy-five insufficient funds checks
  from 2000 to 2002.Â  Another trust account was assessed approximately 11
  insufficient funds fees during the same time period.
A
  bank, where Smalls maintained a trust account and a general operating account,
  force-closed the accounts in 2002.Â  Upon force-closure, the trust account had a
  balance of negative $413.57, and the bank returned approximately thirty-five
  checks in the last seven business days totaling approximately $75,000 due to
  insufficient funds.Â  The general operating account had a balance of negative $44.69.
The Lawyersâ€™
  Fund for Client Protection received claims totaling $235,528.82, and the Fund
  paid out a total of $114,239.04 to forty-seven people.Â  The Fund received
  $33,541.71 from the appointed Trustee resulting in a net deficit of $80,697.33.
In addition to the above
  misconduct, Smalls represented a client in a workersâ€™ compensation case, which
  settled for $7,000 in November 2001.Â  The funds were not disbursed to the
  client prior to Smallsâ€™ interim suspension on May 16, 2002.Â  Next, a
  chiropractor treated one of Smallsâ€™ clients.Â  The client assigned part of her
  settlement to the chiropractor, and the client settled in April 2002.Â  The
  chiropractor was not paid.Â  Lastly, a court reporter submitted an invoice for a
  deposition transcript on or about March 14, 2002 for $342.20.Â  Smalls stipulated
  this invoice was not paid as he was out of the office due to illness and then
  suspended.
Upon review of the
  stipulation of facts and hearing testimony, the panel recommended retroactive
  disbarment, payment of costs, and restitution.Â  Smalls challenged the panelâ€™s
  report and recommendation.
II.
The
  panel found clear and convincing evidence of violations of Rules 1.15, 8.4(a),
  8.4(b), 8.4(d), and 8.4(e), RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The panel further found a
  violation of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  The panel recommended disbarring Smalls
  retroactively, assessing costs against Smalls, and requiring Smalls to make
  full restitution to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund and to victims.Â  We agree and find
  retroactive disbarment, imposition of costs, and restitution warranted.
Rule
  1.15 requires the safekeeping of a clientâ€™s property.Â  The evidence indicated
  Smalls failed to maintain the records of his trust accounts and failed to
  maintain the integrity of his trust accounts.Â  Accordingly, we agree that Rule
  1.15 was violated.Â  Next, we hold subsections (a), (b), (d), and (e) of Rule
  8.4 were violated through Smalls mishandling of clientsâ€™ funds.Â 
  Lastly, we hold the financial recordkeeping requirements of Rule 417 were ignored.
We
  acknowledge it is unclear whether Smalls used the unaccounted for money for his
  personal benefit.Â  What is clear, however, is that Smalls drastically failed to
  keep clientsâ€™ property safe and mishandled money, moving funds from one account
  to another to cover shortages.Â  Accordingly, we find that disbarment is an
  appropriate sanction under these circumstances.Â  Based on precedent and Smallsâ€™
  interim suspension since May 16, 2002, we find imposing a sanction of
  retroactive disbarment adequately protects the public.Â  See In the Matter of
    Yarborough, 380 S.C. 104, 106, 668 S.E.2d 802, 803 (2008) (disbarring
  retroactively given the duration of Yarboroughâ€™s indefinite suspension,
  Yarboroughâ€™s disciplinary history, and the Courtâ€™s finding the purpose of
  disciplinary proceedings, which is to protect the public and the integrity of
  the legal system, was satisfied by retroactive disbarment); In the Matter of
    Evans, 376 S.C. 483, 484-85, 657 S.E.2d 752, 752-53 (2008) (accepting
  agreement to disbar retroactively due to Evansâ€™ failure to manage staff and
  reconcile her records); In the Matter of Kennedy, 367 S.C. 355, 361, 626
  S.E.2d 341, 345 (2006) (disbarring Kennedy retroactively for failing to follow
  recordkeeping and money handling requirements, periodically using trust money
  to pay Kennedyâ€™s expenses, and additional misconduct such as mail fraud).
Under
  Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR we further require Smalls to contact ODC
  within fifteen days of the filing of this opinion regarding setting up a restitution
  plan for the Lawyersâ€™ Fund and other victims, to agree on a payment plan with
  ODC within sixty days of the filing of this opinion, to make payment of the costs
  associated with the disciplinary proceedings within ninety days of the filing
  of this opinion, and to take the Legal Ethics and
  Practice Program administered by ODC prior to any petition for
  reinstatement.Â  Failure to comply with the restitution plan may result in the
  imposition of civil or criminal contempt by this Court.
III.
For
  the foregoing reasons, we retroactively disbar Smalls to the date of his
  interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, Smalls
  shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied
  with Rule 30, Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of
  Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.
DISBARRED.
WALLER, ACTING
  CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E.
  Moore, concur.

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and
          William C. Campbell, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for
          Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this
  attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule
  21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to a definite suspension from the practice of law of up to and
  including one (1) year.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a one (1) year
  suspension from the practice of law.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement,
  are as follows.
Matter I
Respondent admits closing a real estate
  purchase transaction for Complainant A, a co-purchaser of the property, without
  a recordable power of attorney for the other co-purchaser of the property.Â  In
  addition, he admits he allowed Complainant A to sign documents for herself and
  as absent co-purchaser after she indicated she had authority to sign for the
  absent co-purchaser even though he did not seek verification of Complainant Aâ€™s
  authority to sign for the co-purchaser.Â  
Respondent admits that the insurance
  payments on the settlement statement were not accurate and did not reflect the
  actual disbursement.Â  Further, respondent admits he failed to insure the title
  insurance on the transaction was in fact issued and that the closing
  instructions were followed.Â  
Respondent admits he failed to
  supervise the paralegal who was handling the transaction and that his lack of
  supervision resulted in mistakes on the settlement statement and mistakes in
  post-closing requirements.Â  
Respondent admits he falsely witnessed
  a signature on a mortgage that was signed by another person.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Regarding this real estate transaction,
  respondent admits he failed to insure that funds were properly credited to his
  trust account prior to disbursement, that he failed to properly maintain client
  ledgers, that he failed to timely reconcile his trust account, and failed to
  follow Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
Matter II
 Respondent admits he failed to refund
  the Complainantsâ€™ fee after he agreed to issue the refund.Â  Respondent states
  he agreed to the refund as an accommodation to the Complainants after they
  declined to pursue their case.Â  Respondent maintains, however, that he had
  performed enough work on the Complainantsâ€™ behalf to entitle him to the fee.Â 
  ODC does not dispute this assertion.Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits
  that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following Rules of Professional
  Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent
  representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and
  promptness in representing client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of matter); Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall not charge or collect
  unreasonable fee); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall not
  disburse funds from an account containing funds of more than one client or
  third person unless the funds to be disbursed have been deposited in the
  account and are collected funds); Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall insure firm has in
  effect measures giving reasonable assurance that non-lawyerâ€™s conduct Â employed
  by lawyer is compatible with professional obligations of lawyer); and Rule 8.4 (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct). Â Further, respondent admits he did not
  comply with the financial recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR. Â In
  addition, respondent admits that his actions constitute grounds for discipline
  under the following provision of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1)
  (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of
  Professional Conduct).Â  
CONCLUSION
We
  accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the
  practice of law for one (1) year.Â  Within fifteen days of the filing of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit demonstrating he has complied with
  the requirements of Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement,
  Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Anthony Rivera, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Berkeley County
Daniel Peeper, Trial Judge 
Roger M. Young, Post-Conviction Relief
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26653
  Submitted April 22, 2009 - Filed May 18,
2009 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
          of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General
          Matthew Friedman, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to consider an order denying petitionerâ€™s
  application for post-conviction relief (PCR) and now reverse, finding trial
counsel ineffective in agreeing to a response to a jury question.
FACTS
Petitioner
  was acquitted of murder but convicted of armed robbery and received a twenty
  year sentence.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed his direct appeal.Â  State v.
    Rivera, Op. No. 2002-UP-544 (S.C. Ct. App filed August 29, 2002).
At
  trial, the Stateâ€™s theory was that although petitioner did not actively
  participate in the murder/robbery, he accompanied the active participants to
  the scene with knowledge that they intended to commit the robbery.Â  The State
  sought to convict petitioner of the murder which occurred in the course of the
  robbery under a â€œhand of one/hand of allâ€ accomplice liability theory.Â  See State v. Curry, 370 S.C. 674, 636 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The
  Stateâ€™s case relied heavily on petitionerâ€™s incriminating statement, and the
  thrust of the defense was to attack the voluntariness of that statement.
The jury was charged on its duty to determine whether
  petitioner made the statement, and whether the statement was given freely and
  voluntarily.Â  After two hours of deliberation, the jury sent this note:

  Can we
    use the defendentâ€™s [sic] statement for one charge and not the other if we
    think he was deceived prior to giving his statement?

After some discussion, the
  court gave the following written response, without objection:

  Yes -
    if you find the statement was freely and voluntarily made as to one charge but
    not the other.Â  
  No - if
    you find it was not freely and voluntarily made as to both charges.

The note was
  received at 3:25 pm.Â  Some discussion ensued before the written note and answer
  were sent back to the jury.Â  At 3:29 pm, the jury returned to the courtroom
  with its verdict, finding petitioner guilty of armed robbery but acquitting him
  of the murder charge.Â  Immediately after the jury was excused, trial counsel
  asked for a new trial on the ground that the answer given was incorrect in that
  a statement is either voluntary or involuntary in toto.Â  The motion was
  denied. 
At the PCR hearing,
  petitioner contended trial counsel was ineffective in agreeing to the trial
  judgeâ€™s answer to the juryâ€™s inquiry.Â  Trial counsel testified that he was in
  error in failing to object to the answer.Â  The PCR judge denied relief,
  holding:

  [Trial
    judgeâ€™s] response to the jury question was a correct statement of South Carolina law concerning the voluntariness of a statement.Â  Counsel cannot be
    ineffective for failing to raise an issue that is without merit.

We granted
  certiorari to review this ruling.
ISSUE

  
    Did the PCR judge err in failing to find petitionerâ€™s trial
      counsel ineffective?
  

ANALYSIS
In
  order to obtain relief on a claim of ineffective assistance, the applicant must
  demonstrate both that counselâ€™s performance fell below professional norms, and
  that the applicant suffered prejudice as a result of counselâ€™s deficient
  performance.Â  Prejudice is defined as a reasonable probability that had trial
  counsel not been deficient, the result at trial would have been different.Â  E.g., Miller v. State, 379 S.C. 108, 665 S.E.2d 596 (2008).Â  Where a PCR
  judgeâ€™s ruling is controlled by an error of law, this Court will reverse.Â  Council
    v. State, 380 S.C. 159, 670 S.E.2d 356 (2008).
The
  trial court erred in instructing the jury that a statement could be voluntary
  as to one offense but involuntary as to another.Â  Further, the PCR judge
  committed an error of law in holding this charge was a proper statement of law.Â 
  We find no evidence to support the PCR finding that counsel was not deficient
  in agreeing to allow this answer to be given to the jury.Â  The nature of the
  juryâ€™s inquiry, and its immediate return of a split verdict upon receiving the
  answer, convinces us that the jury agreed there was an element of
  involuntariness in petitionerâ€™s statement.Â  Under these circumstances,
  petitioner has demonstrated the requisite prejudice, that is, a reasonable
  probability that had the jury been instructed that a statement is either
  voluntary or involuntary, it would have found petitionerâ€™s statement
  involuntary and acquitted him of the armed robbery charge as well as the murder
  charge.
CONCLUSION
The
  order denying petitioner PCR is
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Petitioners Raphael
  Hernandez, Honorio Guerrero, and Alfredo Avila-Arjona were convicted of trafficking marijuana and sentenced
  to twenty-five years imprisonment.Â  The
  court of appeals affirmed Petitionersâ€™ convictions and sentences.Â  State
    v. Hernandez, Op. No. 2007-UP-183 (S.C.
