that decision and now reverse.

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
At a border crossing in Laredo, Texas, federal officials
  stopped and searched an eighteen-wheeler tractor-trailer (â€œtractor-trailerâ€)
  entering the United States from Mexico.Â  The officials discovered approximately 900 pounds of marijuana concealed
  in a shipment of wooden furniture destined for Tienda DeLeon in Trenton, South
  Carolina.Â  Agents found the marijuana
  compressed into bricks and hidden inside twenty-three wooden chimneys.Â  The officials seized the shipment, replaced
  the driver with an undercover agent, and continued transporting it to
  
      
  South Carolina for a
  controlled delivery.Â  
When the tractor-trailer arrived at Tienda DeLeon,
  Fredy DeLeon,[1] the
  owner of the store, along with two other individuals who arrived at Tienda
  DeLoen in a Ford Thunderbird unloaded several pieces of furniture.Â  The three men then directed the undercover
  agents to transport the rest of the shipment to Billyâ€™s Super Store, also
  located in Trenton. 
The undercover agents drove the tractor-trailer to Billyâ€™s
  Super Store as directed and parked it next to the loading bay.Â  After approximately twenty-five minutes, the
  agents witnessed the same Thunderbird they saw at Tienda DeLeon drive past
  Billyâ€™s Super Store and reappear a few minutes later along with a Ryder moving
  truck (â€œthe Ryder truckâ€) driven by Petitioner Guerrero and with Petitioners Avila-Arjona
  and Hernandez as passengers.Â  The
  Thunderbird pulled beside the tractor-trailer, and the Ryder truck parked in
  front of the tractor-trailer.Â  The
  passenger of the Thunderbird exited the car and attempted to enter the cab of
  the tractor-trailer, but the undercover agent indicated that he was not allowed
  inside the tractor-trailer.Â  The
  Thunderbird passenger then directed the undercover agents to follow him, while
  the driver of the Thunderbird spoke with Petitioners who were still in the
  Ryder truck.Â  The three vehicles formed a
  caravan, with the Thunderbird leading, followed by the Ryder truck, and the
  tractor-trailer in the rear.Â  
The caravan drove down a dirt road for a while.Â  Subsequently, the Ryder truck and the
  tractor-trailer became stuck in the mud.Â  The undercover agents decided to call off the operation and promptly
  arrested Petitioners.Â  The Thunderbird
  drove away and the men were never apprehended.Â  The agents searched the Ryder truck and found the cargo portion of the
  truck empty.Â  However, the agents
  discovered a receipt indicating that Petitioner Guerrero rented the Ryder truck
  the day before and a receipt from a motel for the night before the controlled
  delivery took place.Â  
Petitioners were indicted for trafficking
  marijuana.Â  At trial, Petitioners moved
  for a directed verdict claiming that the State had only proved mere presence at
  the scene and had failed to prove the element of knowledge.Â  The trial court denied Petitionersâ€™ motion,
  and the court of appeals affirmed, holding that there was substantial
  circumstantial evidence to send the case to the jury.Â  
This Court granted Petitionersâ€™ request for a writ of
  certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision, and Petitioners present
  the following issue for review:

  Did the court of appeals err in affirming the trial
    courtâ€™s denial of Petitionersâ€™ directed verdict motion because the State only
    proved mere presence?

STANDARD OF
REVIEW
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the
  trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not
  its weight. Â State v. Weston, 367
  S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006).Â  A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict
  when the state fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â 
      
      
      Id. Â When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict,
  an appellate court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the
  light most favorable to the State.Â 
      
      
      Id. Â If there is any direct evidence or
  substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of
  the accused, the Court must find the case was properly
  submitted to the jury.Â 
      
     
      Id.
  at 292-93, 625 S.E.2d at 648.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioners argue the court of
  appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of their motion for a
  directed verdict.Â  We agree. 
In relevant part, South Carolinaâ€™s definition of trafficking
  marijuana includes: â€œAny person . . . who is
  knowingly in actual or constructive possession or who knowingly attempts to
  become in actual or constructive possessionâ€ of ten pounds or more of
  marijuana.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370
  (Supp. 2006).Â  In drug cases, the
  element of knowledge is seldom established through direct evidence, but may be
  proven circumstantially.Â  State v. Attardo, 263
  S.C. 546, 550, 211 S.E.2d 868, 869 (1975).Â  Knowledge can be proven
  by the evidence of acts, declarations, or conduct of the accused from which the
  inference may be drawn that the accused knew of the existence of the prohibited
  substances.Â 
      
      
      Id.
At
  trial, the State presented two receipts indicating
  that Petitioners traveled to Trenton for the night and rented the Ryder
  truck.Â  The undercover agent testified
  that Petitioners conversed with the driver of the Thunderbird before they
caravanned down the rural dirt road.Â  Additionally, the undercover
  agent testified that in his experience, drug transactions this large are
  typically handled within an â€œinner circleâ€ and all of the parties involved are
aware of what transpires.Â  

 In our view, this evidence does not
  constitute substantial circumstantial evidence of knowledge.Â  The State failed to present evidence
  connecting Petitioners to the tractor-trailer or to Fredy DeLeon or evidence
  that Petitioners had knowledge of the contents of the tractor-trailer.Â  The State claims that it is â€œnonsensicalâ€ to
  find that the Thunderbird occupants did not know Petitioners prior to this
  transaction.Â  However, the State failed
  to present any evidence such as acts, declarations, or specific conduct to
  support this inference, and thus, we find that the conclusion that Petitioners
  knew the Thunderbird occupants and therefore had knowledge of the drugs in the
  tractor trailer is mere speculation.Â  Additionally, the State points to the testimony of the federal agents to
  support the inference that Petitioners had knowledge of the drugs.Â  We find, however, that while these
  testimonies may support such an inference, this evidence alone does not
  constitute substantial circumstantial evidence that Petitioners had knowledge.Â  See State
    v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 584, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001) (reversing the
  defendantâ€™s conviction where the State did not present substantial
  circumstantial evidence and where the evidence merely raised a suspicion of
  guilt).Â  
Although Petitionersâ€™ actions may have
  been suspicious, mere suspicion is insufficient to support the verdict.[2]Â  State v. Arnold, 361
  S.C. 386, 605 S.E.2d 529 (2004)
  (holding that the trial court must grant a directed verdict when the evidence
  merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty).Â  Accordingly, we reverse Petitionersâ€™
  convictions and sentences. 
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, we reverse the
  court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  
WALLER,
  KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justices James E. Moore and James A. Spruill,
concur.


[1] Fredy DeLeon was tried and convicted with
Petitioners but is not a party in this appeal.Â  
[2] The traditional circumstantial evidence charge
  provides that when the State relies on circumstantial evidence to prove its
  case, the jury may not convict the defendant unless:

  Every circumstance relied upon by the State be proven
    beyond a reasonable doubt; and . . . all of the circumstances so proven be
    consistent with each other and taken together, point conclusively to the guilt
    of the accused to the exclusion of every other reasonable hypothesis.

State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 275, 379 S.E.2d 888, 889 (1989).Â  Although in State
  v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 606
  S.E.2d 475 (2004) the Court abandoned this charge and held that it may confuse a
  jury by leading it to believe that the standard for measuring
  circumstantial evidence is different from that for measuring direct evidence,
it nonetheless illustrates the lack of evidence against Petitioners.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Larry M.
          Ferguson, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal From Anderson County
  Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  26655
Heard March 17, 2009 - Filed May 26, 2009Â  

REMANDED


  
    
      
        Chief
          Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
          Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Daniel E.
          Grigg, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ dismissal of this appeal.[1]Â 
  The sole issue is whether mental incapacity tolls the statute of limitations in
  which to file for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  
FACTS
In December 1996,
  Petitioner, Larry Ferguson, pleaded guilty to first degree burglary, second
  degree burglary, grand larceny (three counts), and receiving stolen goods; he
  was sentenced to fifteen years, suspended on five years probation.[2]Â 
  In March 2001, Ferguson pleaded guilty to numerous drug charges for which he
  was concurrently sentenced to two years on each offense; his probation on the
  1996 charges was revoked in full.Â  
In February 2002, Ferguson filed an application for PCR alleging ineffective assistance in connection with
  the 1996 guilty plea.Â  The application was dismissed after a hearing, on the
  ground that it was barred by the one-year statute of limitations set forth in
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(a).Â  We granted certiorari.
ISSUE
Is the one-year
  statute of limitations set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(a) tolled by a
  PCR applicantâ€™s mental incapacity?
DISCUSSION
S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-27-45(a) provides:

  (A) An
    application for relief filed pursuant to this chapter must be filed within one
    year after the entry of a judgment of conviction or within one year after the
    sending of the remittitur to the lower court from an appeal or the filing of
    the final decision upon an appeal, whichever is later.

Peloquin v. State, 321 S.C. 468, 469 S.E.2d 606 (1996).
The PCR court held
  the one-year statute of limitations was not tolled by an applicantâ€™s mental
  incompetency, citing our opinion in Council v. Catoe, 359 S.C. 120, 597
  S.E.2d 782 (2004).Â  In Council, we addressed whether PCR proceedings of
  a mentally incompetent applicant should be indefinitely stayed until
  such time as the applicant regained competency.Â  We held collateral review of the
  trial proceedings should not be delayed due to the applicantâ€™s incompetency.Â 
  359 S.C. at 129, 597 S.E.2d at 787.Â  The basis for our holding was that the
  issues on PCR were not â€œextraordinarily fact intensiveâ€ and did not require
  Councilâ€™s assistance.Â  Accordingly, Councilâ€™s incompetent state did not prevent
  the PCR court from proceeding on those issues.Â  We went on to note, however, that
  â€œif, at a future date, the petitioner regains his competency and discovers that
  at his original PCR hearing, his incompetency prevented his ability to assist
  his counsel on a fact-based claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, he may
  then raise that claim in a subsequent proceeding.â€Â  Id.[3]Â  
The State and Ferguson fervently dispute the import of the Courtâ€™s holding in Council.[4]Â 
  In light of the language a PCR applicantâ€™s mental incompetency does not delay
  collateral proceedings, the State interprets Council to mean that the
  statute of limitations is not tolled during incompetency.Â  Ferguson, on the
  other hand, contends the holding in Council that a mentally
  incompetent applicant who later regains competence will have an opportunity to raise fact-based issues at a later date, is an implicit holding that the
  statute of limitations is tolled.Â Â Â  
Unlike Council,
  the issue here is not whether PCR proceedings should be stayed by virtue
  of Fergusonâ€™s alleged incompetency but, rather, whether or not the time in
  which to file an application for PCR is tolled.Â  
There is a split of
  authority as to whether the statute of limitations to file a PCR action is
  tolled by mental incompetency.Â  It has been held that while an ongoing mental
  incompetence may warrant equitable tolling, â€œa claim of mental incompetence
  does not constitute a per se reason to toll a statute of limitations. .
  . . Rather, the critical inquiry remains whether the circumstances preventing a
  petitioner from making a timely filing were both beyond the petitioner's
  control and unavoidable despite due diligence.â€Â  Com. v. Carneal, ___
  S.W.3d ___ (Ky. 2008), internal citations omitted; Nara v. Frank,
  264 F.3d 310, 320 (3d Cir.2001), overruled on other grounds by Carey
    v. Saffold, 536 U .S. 214 (2002) (mental incompetence may warrant equitable
  tolling where alleged mental incompetence has affected petitionerâ€™s ability to
  timely file); State v. Nix, 40 S.W.3d 459 (Tenn. 2001) (due process
  requires tolling of PCR statute of limitations only if petitioner is unable to
  manage his affairs or understand his legal rights and liabilities); Seals v.
    Tennessee, 23 S.W.3d 272, 277 (Tenn. 2000) (due process considerations may
  toll statute of limitations if mentally incompetent petitioner was denied the
  opportunity to bring a claim in a â€œmeaningful time and mannerâ€).Â  But see Allen v. State, ___ So.2d___ (Miss. App. 2008), citing House
    v. State, 754 So2d 1147 (Miss. 1999) (holding there is no authority to toll
  statute of limitations based on mental incompetence).Â  
Although we have
  not specifically addressed tolling the statute of limitations in the context of
  mentally incompetent PCR applicants,[5] case law warrants a holding that, in circumstances in which an applicant
  demonstrates the failure to timely file for PCR was due to mental incompetency,
  the statute should be tolled.Â Â  
In Odom v. State,
  337 S.C. 256, 523 S.E.2d 753 (1999), we held the one year statute of
  limitations of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A), does not apply to Austin v.
    State[6] appeals.Â  In Austin, counsel failed to file a timely appeal following
  the denial of the petitionerâ€™s PCR application. He filed a subsequent PCR
  application claiming ineffective assistance of counsel during his first
  application for PCR. Â We remanded for an evidentiary hearing to determine
  whether petitioner requested and was denied the right to appeal.Â  We held Austin appeals need not be filed within the one year statute of limitations because
  they are belated appeals intended to correct unjust procedural defects.Â  â€œUnder
  the PCR rules, an applicant is entitled to a full adjudication on the merits of
  the original petition, or â€œone bite at the apple.â€Â  Odom, 337
  S.C. at 261, 523 S.E.2d at 755, citing Aice v. State, 305 S.C.
  448, 452, 409 S.E.2d 392, 395 (1991) (emphasis added).
The rule of Odom and Austin was extended in Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 559
  S.E.2d 581 (2002).Â  In Wilson, we held every defendant has a right to
  file a direct appeal and one PCR application.Â  There, since counsel had been
  ineffective in failing to file an appeal, and the statute of limitations in
  which to file for PCR had expired, we held â€œpolicy would be frustrated if the
  one year statute of limitations for PCR claims applied where the applicant was
  denied his direct appeal due to ineffective assistance of counsel, and then was
  denied his right to a PCR application because of the one year statute of
  limitations.â€Â  Id. at 218, 559 S.E.2d at 583.Â  
The same policy
  considerations are applicable here.Â  If Ferguson was prevented from filing for
  PCR by reason of his mental incompetency, then he has not, and will not,
  receive his one full bite at the apple.Â  Accordingly, we find the proper remedy
  is to remand to the PCR court for a hearing as to whether Fergusonâ€™s mental
  incapacity prevented such an application in the one year following his 1996
  guilty plea.Â  If the PCR court finds mental incompetence prevented his filing a
  PCR application, the court should determine the duration of the incompetence,
  and whether the application was filed within one year of Ferguson regaining
  competency.Â  PCR should proceed only if Fergusonâ€™s application was timely filed
  within one year of the date that he regained competence.Â  
REMANDED.

TOAL, C.J.,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.

[1] Â We reinstated the appeal and granted
  certiorari.
[2]Â  Ferguson was 18 years old at the time of his 1996 plea.Â  He has a history of mental
  illness, bi-polar disorder, and has an IQ of 76.Â  
[3]Â  We recently held a mentally incompetent capital
  defendant could not waive his right to pursue PCR.Â  Hughes v. State, 367
  S.C. 389, 626 S.E.2d 805 (2006).
[4]Â  Initially, the State contends there is no
  evidence of incompetence subsequent to Fergusonâ€™s 1996 plea.Â  However, that
  matter was not addressed at PCR and no hearing held on that claim inasmuch as
  the court held the statute of limitations barred his action.Â  
[5] Â In Norris v. State, 335 S.C. 30, 515
  S.E.2d 523 (1999), we found it unnecessary to address whether mental
  incompetency tolled the statute of limitations for PCR applications.
[6] Â 305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d 395 (1991).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        James C.
          Blackburn, Respondent,
        v.
        Daufuskie
          Island Fire District, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26656
Heard March 18, 2009 - Filed May 26, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Caroline
          W. Cleveland, of Cleveland Law, LLC, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        James
          B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
        Adelaide S. Andrews, of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae City of Charleston.
        Jeffrey
          A. Lehrer, of Ford & Harrison, of Spartanburg, for Amicus Curiae City of Spartanburg.
        Shahin
          Vafai and Linda Pearce Edwards, both of Gignilliat, Savitz & Bettis, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae Municipal Association of South Carolina.
        W.
          A. Nickles, III, of Gergel Nickles & Solomon, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae City of Columbia.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  In this declaratory judgment action, appellant Daufuskie Island
  Fire District directly appeals from the Master-in-Equityâ€™s decision that under
  the emergency leave portion of the South Carolina military leave statute,
  â€œthirty daysâ€ means thirty work days, as opposed to thirty calendar days.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS[1]
Appellant is a Special Purpose Tax District within Beaufort County which provides fire protection services to the residents of Daufuskie Island.Â  Appellant employed respondent, James C. Blackburn, as a firefighter from
  July 2002 until his resignation in December 2005.Â  Respondentâ€™s normal work
  schedule as a firefighter consisted of 24-hours on duty, followed by 48-hours
  off duty (â€œ24/48â€).Â  Respondentâ€™s 24-hour working period would begin at 8:15
  a.m. on one calendar day, and conclude at 8:15 a.m. the following day.Â 
  Generally, respondent worked ten 24-hour shifts per month.
Respondent was compensated every two weeks, for a total of 26
  times per year.Â  The 24/48 schedule meant that respondent would work 120 hours
  for two pay periods in a row, and then 96 hours for the next consecutive pay
  period.Â  Nonetheless, appellantâ€™s pay practices provided for uniform payments
  every two weeks equivalent to pay for 112 hours, i.e., the average hours worked
  over the course of three pay periods.[2]Â  
In addition to being a firefighter, respondent is a sergeant in
  the United States Air Force Reserve.Â  While employed by appellant, respondent
  had a number of work absences due to his military duties.Â  Some of these
  military absences were for annual training, i.e., regular military leave, but
  others were for tours of active duty, considered emergency leave.
Respondent
  filed a declaratory action seeking a determination that under the South Carolina military leave statute, he was entitled to be paid for 30 work days of
  emergency military leave.Â  The parties filed cross-motions for summary
  judgment, and the Master found in respondentâ€™s favor.Â  Specifically, the Master
  ruled that under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-7-90, respondent was entitled to 30 work days
  of emergency leave, and the measure of respondentâ€™s work day was â€œhis usual 24-hour
  shift.â€[3]
ISSUE

  Did the Master err in ruling that the â€œthirty additional daysâ€ of
    emergency leave provided under S.C. Code Ann Â§ 8-7-90 refers to 30 work days as
    opposed to 30 calendar days?

DISCUSSION
Appellant argues the Master erred in interpreting the emergency
  leave provision of section 8-7-90.Â  Appellant contends that for this portion of
  the statute, the phrase â€œthirty additional daysâ€ means thirty calendar days.Â  We
  disagree.
The
  cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the
  intent of the legislature.Â  E.g., Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79,
  85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  Moreover, â€œ[w]ords must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without
  resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s
  operation.â€Â  Sloan v. Hardee, 371 S.C. 495, 499, 640 S.E.2d 457,
  459 (2007). 
The
  statute regarding public employeesâ€™ payment for military leave has evolved over
  the years.Â  Prior to a 1990 amendment, section 8-7-90 read as follows:

  All
    officers and employees of this State or a political subdivision of this State
    who are either enlisted or commissioned members of the South Carolina National
    Guard, the United States Naval Reserve, the Officers Reserve Corps, or the
    Enlisted Reserve Corps, the Reserve Corps of the Marines, the Coast Guard
    Reserve and the United States Air Force Reserve shall be entitled to leave of
    absence from their respective duties without loss of pay, time, or efficiency
    rating for a period not exceeding fifteen days in any one year during
    which they may be engaged in training or other such duties ordered by the
    Governor, the War Department, the Treasury Department, the Navy Department, or
    the Air Force Department.Â  In the event any such person is called upon to
      serve during an emergency he shall be entitled to such leave of absence for not
      exceeding thirty additional days. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-7-90
  (1986) (emphasis added). 
The
  current version, which reflects the 1990 amendment, provides as follows: 

  All
    officers and employees of this State or a political subdivision of this State
    who are either enlisted or commissioned members of the South Carolina National
    Guard, the United States Army Reserve, the United States Air Force Reserve, the
    United States Naval Reserve, the United States Marine Corps Reserve, or the
    United States Coast Guard Reserve are entitled to leaves of absence from their
    respective duties without loss of pay, time, or efficiency rating for one or
      more periods not exceeding an aggregate of fifteen regularly scheduled work
        days in any one year during which they may engage in training or any other
    duties ordered by the Governor, the Department of Defense, the Department of
    the Army, the Department of the Air Force, the Department of the Navy, the
    Department of the Treasury, or any other department or agency of the government
    of the United States having authority to issue lawful orders requiring military
    service.Â  Saturdays, Sundays, and state holidays may not be included in the
      fifteen-day aggregate unless the particular Saturday, Sunday, or holiday to be
      included is a regularly scheduled work day for the officer or employee
      involved.Â  In the event any such person is called upon to serve during an
      emergency he is entitled to such leave of absence for not exceeding thirty additional
      days. 
  As used in this section, â€˜in any one yearâ€™
    means either a calendar year or, in the case of members required to perform
    active duty for training or other duties within or on a fiscal year basis, the
    fiscal year of the National Guard or reserve component issuing the orders. 
  The provisions of this section must be
    construed liberally to encourage and
    allow full participation in all aspects of the National Guard and reserve
    programs of the armed forces of the United States and to allow state officers
    and employees who are enlisted or commissioned members of the National Guard or
    reserve components to excel in military and emergency preparedness and service
    by taking full advantage of all career-enhancing assignments and training
    opportunities.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-7-90 (Supp.
  2008) (emphasis added).[4]
Thus, before 1990,
  the language of the statute simply stated that employees were entitled to a
  leave of absence â€œfor a period not exceeding fifteen days in any one
  year.â€ Â Â§ 8-7-90 (1986) (emphasis added).Â  Significantly, the 1990 amendment
  made the following changes:Â  (1) modified the above phrase to â€œfor one or more periods not exceeding an aggregate of fifteen regularly scheduled work days;â€ (2) added the sentence specifying
  that weekends and holidays are not to be included in the 15-day
  aggregate (unless these days are â€œregularly scheduled workâ€ days); and (3)
  added express language that the statute is to be construed liberally to
  encourage and allow full participation in all aspects of the military
  reserves.Â  The 1990 amendment did not fundamentally change the sentence
  concerning â€œemergencyâ€ leave.
Appellant maintains
  that because the Legislature only changed â€œdaysâ€ to â€œwork daysâ€ in the
  sentences expressly relating to the aggregate 15-day â€œregularâ€ training period,
  the word â€œdaysâ€ in the emergency leave sentence does not mean work days, but
  instead means calendar days.Â  In our opinion, however, a plain, unforced
  reading of the statute actually points to the opposite conclusion.Â  See Sloan
    v. Hardee, supra.
The
  first sentence of the statute speaks of an employeeâ€™s entitlement to military
  â€œleaves of absences.â€Â  While that sentence goes on to discuss â€œregularâ€ leaves
  of absences, the final sentence of the first paragraph refers to emergency
  leave, and then states that an employee is â€œentitled to such leave of
  absence for not exceeding thirty additional days.â€Â  Â§ 8-7-90 (Supp.
  2008) (emphasis added). The phrase, â€œsuch leave,â€ plainly means the type of
  leave the statute has already discussed earlier in the same paragraph;
  namely, a military leave of absence based upon regularly scheduled work days.[5]Â  
Appellant also contends
  that the majority of state jurisdictions facing this issue have found that the
  word â€œdaysâ€ in the military leave statute refers to â€œcalendar days.â€Â  As
  pointed out by the Master, however, these authorities weigh in favor of
  respondentâ€™s position because those state statutes use the unmodified â€œdays,â€
  whereas South Carolinaâ€™s statute speaks in terms of â€œwork days.â€Â  See, e.g., Koppin v. Strode, 761 N.E.2d 455 (Ind. Ct. App. 2002) (rejecting
  firefightersâ€™ argument that a day should be based on a 24-hour shift, and
  instead interpreting 15 days in the military leave statute as 15 eight-hour
  days); Painters and Allied Trades Local Union 246 v. City of Des Moines,
  451 N.W.2d 825, 826 (Iowa 1990) (holding that statute which allows municipal
  employees a leave of absence for military service â€œwithout loss of pay during
  the first thirty days of such leave of absenceâ€ meant calendar days, not
  working days); Glass v. City of Lynn, 729 N.E.2d 1136 (Mass. App. Ct.
  2000) (rejecting police officerâ€™s claim that statute entitling paid military
  leave for 17 â€œdaysâ€ did not allow compensation for seventeen work days); Smith v. School Dist. No. 1, 578 P.2d 820 (Or. Ct. App. 1978) (holding that
  the state statute entitling public employees to paid military leave for â€œa
  period not exceeding 15 daysâ€ meant no more than 15 consecutive calendar days).
 In contrast, those
  jurisdictions where the statute expressly defines military leave by work days
  have interpreted firefightersâ€™ claims just as the Master did in this case.Â  For
